mxCell.value: Time
This is an Event Modeling example board. The hotel example is taken from https://eventmodeling.org/posts/what-is-event-modeling/

The original example that you can find on the website linked above was created with Miro/Realtimeboard. Our version is very similar but contains some additions. We've added feature frames (learn more about them here) to vertically slice through the swim lanes and group features/use cases. On this small example board the effect isn't that big, but with more content on the board, features will help you navigate and keep an overview. Check out the context tree on the left sidebar to see the effect.

Event Modeling came out while we were already working on and with InspectIO. It heavily influenced the way we organize stickies on the board. Our best practice is documented on the InspectIO Example Board. Make sure to check it out.

However, our approach is focused on Design-Level Event Storming since we use Bounded Contexts, Aggregates and Hot Spots. Event Modeling on the other hand wants to minimize the number of required stickies (and therefor concepts) to make communication with business people as simple as possible. This moves some information back to the implementation, for example what piece of code handles a command. What are the business rules and so on. 

 For us there is no clear winner at the moment. The simplicity of Event Modeling is definitely an advantage. On the other hand some details are missing that we usually discuss before implementing them. So it's a team choice what you prefer. It might also make sense to combine the approaches: 

You can start with Big Picture Event Storming. After that use Event Modeling to explore details together with domain experts, UX Designer, .... Once boundaries are clear (the swim lanes in Event Modeling), each team can use Design-Level Event Storming to work out and discuss implementation details.

InspectIO is in closed beta. We're focusing on stability and usability of the service. Once stable, we want to improve Event Modeling support, especially working with swim lanes instead of Bounded Context frames. For now you have to use some tricks to create the swim lanes. 

Here is how we did it: 

1) The timeline starts with a dot icon.

2) It ends with a comment box that contains the word "time". 

3) In between the two is a connector arrow. 

4) The height of the "time" comment box is the same as the entire height of the diagram, but it has no border and a transparent bg. Line breaks are used to vertically align the word "time" with the timeline arrow.

5) The swim lanes are created the same. Each starts with a comment box that holds the label of the swim lane. 

6) An arrow connects the label with the "time" comment.

7) The dashed style of the arrows can be chosen from the context menu (right click on an arrow). 

Please note: It's planned to move arrow styling into a format toolbar. So this is subject to change, like other usability aspects of InspectIO.

    The "time" comment box trick has the advantage that all arrows are connected with it. If you need to expand the timeline, just move the "time" comment to the right and all arrows and therefor all swim lanes will be resized accordingly.

Instead of swim lanes you could also use the bounded context frames. We do this on one of our production boards to get the advantage of better readability in the "bird view" (zoomed out) and grouping in the context tree.

You might wonder why InspectIO does not simply offer some more drawing options. The reason for that is the same as why Event Modeling wants to reduce the number of sticky types: simplicity. The less you have to think about how you display information, the more you can concentrate on the business problems and proper solutions. 

InspectIO is not meant to be a drawing or general purpose diagramming tool. The provided elements all have a specific meaning. This allows us to analyze the content of a board and provide features that a general purpose online whiteboarding tool cannot provide. The context tree on the sidebar is one example. We have much more in the pipeline, like code generation, project management stuff and so on. For Event Modeling this means, that we want to add swim lane elements similar to the Bounded Contexts frames available for Design-Level Event Storming.
